Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I was waiting at the taxi stand when my phone buzzed. It was my stepbrother, his voice trembling as he told me about the bad news—something about our dad’s health. He needed me, just to talk, to be there. My heart twisted; I knew he counted on me, especially since we’d promised to support each other after our parents married. But just then, two travelers approached, dragging heavy suitcases. “Can you help us load these? We’ll split the fare,” one said, glancing at the meter. I glanced at my phone, my brother’s name still on the screen, and then at the travelers, who were clearly in a hurry. As a taxi driver, I was expected to be professional, efficient, and helpful—no time for personal calls or distractions. But as a step-sibling, I was supposed to be present, to listen, to comfort. My hands hovered over the trunk, my mind racing between the weight of my brother’s pain and the immediate demands of my job. I could feel the pressure building, torn between being the sibling he needed and the driver my passengers expected.
